Scenario: Pregnant - suspected/confirmed rubella or possible exposure
Suspected or confirmed rubella in pregnancy
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage suspected or confirmed rubella in a pregnant woman?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If rubella is suspected in a pregnant woman:

  • Contact the local Health Protection Team immediately.
    • Rubella is a notifiable disease:
      • Information on how to report a notifiable disease is available from the Public Health England website.
      • Information on how to report a notifiable in Scotland is available from the Health Protection Scotland website.
    • Pregnancies of less than 20 weeks' gestation are at greatest risk of complications from rubella exposure, however, investigation is required regardless of previous testing, immunization status or stage of pregnancy.
    • The Health Protection Team will advise on appropriate investigations — depending on the clinical situation, testing for other infections with similar clinical features (such as parvovirus B19 and measles) may carried out simultaneously:
      • Clearly state on requests that the patient is pregnant and ensure details accompanying samples are accurate and complete.
      • Discuss with the Health Protection Team who will supply the test results and arrange ongoing management in pregnancy if rubella is confirmed.
  • If rubella infection is confirmed and the woman is 20 weeks or less pregnant or there is any doubt about the gestational age:
    • Refer urgently to obstetrics (fetal medicine) for risk-assessment and counselling. Risk to the fetus is dependent on stage of pregnancy:
      • Beyond 20 weeks' gestation there have been no published case reports of Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS).
      • Between 16–20 weeks' gestation there is a low chance of deafness occurring.
      • Between 11–16 weeks' gestation there is a 10–20% risk of CRS, with single defects being most common.
      • Before 8–10 weeks' gestation there is a 90% risk of CRS and a high likelihood of multiple defects.
    • There are no effective treatments to prevent CRS but Human Normal Immunoglobulin may be considered in secondary care. Further diagnostic tests may be indicated (for example amniocentesis or fetal blood sampling).
  • If rubella infection is diagnosed in pregnancy at gestation confirmed to be greater than 20 weeks:
    • The woman can be reassured that there have been no reported cases of CRS after this gestational age.
    • If found to be non-immune — rubella immunization should not be administered in pregnancy but may be given post-partum.
  • If viral pathogens other than rubella are identified:
    • Seek specialist advice on management as some (such as Parvovirus B19, Varicella zoster, Herpes simplex and Cytomegalovirus) are associated with congenital infection.
    • Guidance on Viral Rash in Pregnancy is available from the Public Health England website.
  • Advise all woman with suspected or confirmed infection:
    • On self-care measures — rest and drink adequate fluids. Paracetamol can be taken for symptomatic relief if required.
      • For more information see the CKS topic Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain.
    • To stay off work and avoid contact with other pregnant women — they should inform clinical staff of confirmed or suspected infection prior to attending medical areas until known to be non-infectious or uninfected.
    • To follow general infection control measures (cover their mouth and nose with a disposable tissue and wash hands after using or disposing of tissues) to reduce the risk of transmission to others.
    • To seek urgent medical advice if symptoms do not settle as expected or features suggestive of complications of rubella develop.
      • Arrange urgent assessment in secondary care if serious complications (such as haemorrhagic complications or encephalitis) are suspected.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of suspected or confirmed rubella in pregnancy are based on the clinical guidelines Viral Rash in Pregnancy [HPA, 2011b], UK Standards for Microbiology Investigations. Investigation of Pregnant Women Exposed to Non-Vesicular Rash [PHE, 2015b], Rubella (German measles): guidance, data and analysis [PHE, 2016a], Rubella (German measles, three-day measles) [CDC, 2017], Health protection in schools and other childcare facilities. A practical guide for staff on managing cases of infectious diseases in schools and other childcare settings [PHE, 2017], Rubella in Pregnancy [Dontigny, 2018], the World Health Organization factsheet on Rubella [WHO, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Lambert, 2015; Carruthers et al, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018; Bukasa, 2018].

Notification and confirmation of diagnosis
  • Rubella has been a notifiable disease in the UK since 1988 — health professionals have a legal obligation to report all clinically diagnosed cases. Notification should be based on clinical suspicion and should not await laboratory confirmation [PHE, 2010; PHE, 2013; Bukasa, 2018].
  • Detection, confirmation and classification of all suspected cases is required as part of the commitment of all member states of the World Health Organization (WHO) European Region to eliminate measles and rubella [PHE, 2018b].
Investigation regardless of previous testing, immunization status or stage of pregnancy
  • Most women in the UK receive antenatal screening for rubella antibodies in the early stages of pregnancy [NICE, 2017]. However, further investigation is recommended in pregnant women with a rubella-like rash regardless of the results of previous testing or immunization status. This is because of the possibility of laboratory or documentation error, failed immunization, symptomatic rubella reinfection, or parvovirus B19 infection [Morgan-Capner et al, 2002; HPA, 2011b].
  • Although there have been no case reports of congenital rubella syndrome after 20 weeks' gestation, investigations to confirm the diagnosis are still recommended after this period as [Morgan-Capner et al, 2002; HPA, 2011b]:
    • Specific diagnosis will aid management of contacts.
    • Immunoglobulin assays may provide information on the date of infection in relation to the gestational age.
    • The diagnosis may be helpful for future management, for example, postnatal administration of combined measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.
Vaccination in non-immune women
  • Rubella is preventable by immunisation with 2 doses of the measles mumps rubella (MMR) vaccine — every opportunity to pick up on missed vaccines and ensure high uptake of the MMR vaccine should be taken [PHE, 2017; PHE, 2018b].
    • The Public Health England Guidance on Immunisation (Green Book) [PHE, 2013] states that there is no evidence that rubella-containing vaccines are teratogenic, however, as a precaution, MMR vaccine should not be given to women known to be pregnant and if MMR vaccine is given to adult women, they should be advised to guard against pregnancy for one month.
Investigation for other viruses than can present with similar clinical features
  • PHE guidance recommends that when rubella is suspected, pregnant women should be simultaneously investigated for immunity to both rubella and parvovirus B19 (unless their immune status is already known) [PHE, 2015b].
    • It is important to diagnose parvovirus B19 in pregnant women in the first trimester as there is a 30% risk of transplacental infection, with a 5–9% risk of fetal loss. There is also a risk of hydrops fetalis, and regular ultrasound monitoring (and possible intrauterine fetal infusion) is recommended for those babies at risk [HPA, 2011b].
  • Depending on the specific clinical situation, the Health Protection Team may also recommend testing for other infections which can present with similar clinical features such as measles [PHE, 2016a].
Referral to obstetrics
  • Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) is possible before 20 weeks of gestation, and very probable (and likely to be severe) in the first 10 weeks. It is associated with several serious complications affecting the fetus. The pregnant woman requires urgent referral for counselling and risk-assessment. Human normal immunoglobulin may be considered in specific cases in secondary care [Morgan-Capner et al, 2002; Carruthers et al, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018; PHE, 2018b].
    • Guidance from Public Health England (the Green Book) [PHE, 2013] states that human normal immunoglobulin is not recommended for the protection of pregnant women exposed to rubella and should only be considered when termination of pregnancy is unacceptable.
    • A Cochrane review [Young, 2015] including 7 randomised controlled trials and 5 controlled trials (n=430) assessed the effectiveness of polyclonal immunoglobulins of human sera or plasma origin for preventing rubella and congenital rubella syndrome when administered to exposed susceptible people before onset of disease. The authors found that compared to no treatment, polyclonal immunoglobulins appeared to be of benefit for preventing rubella up to five days after exposure. However, as none of the included studies reported congenital rubella infection as an outcome the authors concluded that there was insufficient evidence on the effectiveness of polyclonal immunoglobulins for preventing congenital rubella syndrome.
  • Information on the likelihood of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) is based on Public Health England guidance [HPA, 2011b; PHE, 2013] and observational data described in narrative reviews [Morgan-Capner et al, 2002; Gershon, 2010].
Self-care advice
  • Adequate fluid intake should be maintained to replace fluid loss, although there have been no controlled trials that have shown the benefit of this [Guppy et al, 2011b].
Prevention of transmission
  • Guidance from Public Health England states that children with suspected rubella should be kept away from school or nursery for 5 days after the development of the rash [PHE, 2016b] and this can be reasonably extrapolated to adults.
  • However, as people can be infectious for 7 days before the onset of the rash to 7-10 days after rash onset [HPA, 2011b; CDC, 2017], CKS recommends it is prudent for the affected person to avoid contact with pregnant women during this time period. Infants with CRS can transmit the virus for up to 1 year after birth [CDC, 2017].

subChapters.fullItemName: Contact with suspected or confirmed rubella in pregnancy
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage contact with suspected or confirmed rubella in pregnancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Contact the local Health Protection Team immediately.
    • If the woman fulfils the criteria for immunity to rubella, investigation for other infections (such as parvovirus B19) may be required.
      • Criteria for immunity to rubella includes at least two previous rubella antibody screening test results that have detected antibodies, or at least two documented doses of rubella vaccine, or a documented dose of rubella vaccine and a previous rubella antibody screening test result which has detected antibodies.
    • If the woman does not fulfil the criteria for immunity to rubella investigations for other infections with similar clinical features (such as parvovirus B19 and measles) may be carried out in addition to rubella.
    • Clearly state on requests that the patient is pregnant and ensure details accompanying samples are accurate and complete.
    • Discuss with the Health Protection Team who will supply the test results and arrange ongoing management in pregnancy if infection is confirmed.
  • Advise the woman to inform their midwife, GP or obstetrician urgently if they develop a rash at any time in pregnancy. Until they are assessed and confirmed to be uninfected or non-infective, they should:
    • Avoid contact with other pregnant women (including in antenatal clinic or maternity settings).
    • Inform clinical staff of suspected infection prior to attending any medical area.
  • Take the opportunity to ensure that the women is fully vaccinated and if not make appropriate arrangements for follow up.
    • If found to be non-immune — rubella immunization should not be administered in pregnancy but may be given post-partum.
    • For further information, See the CKS topic on Immunizations - childhood.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of possible exposure to rubella in pregnancy are based on the clinical guidelines Viral Rash in Pregnancy [HPA, 2011b], UK Standards for Microbiology Investigations. Investigation of Pregnant Women Exposed to Non-Vesicular Rash [PHE, 2015b], Rubella (German measles): guidance, data and analysis [PHE, 2016a], Rubella (German measles, three-day measles) [CDC, 2017], Health protection in schools and other childcare facilities. A practical guide for staff on managing cases of infectious diseases in schools and other childcare settings [PHE, 2017], Rubella in Pregnancy [Dontigny, 2018], the World Health Organization factsheet on Rubella [WHO, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Lambert, 2015; Carruthers et al, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018; Bukasa, 2018].

Need for investigation
  • The Public Health England (PHE) guideline UK Standards for Microbiology Investigations. Investigation of Pregnant Women Exposed to Non-Vesicular Rash [PHE, 2015b] states that:
    • Pregnant contacts of people with maculopapular rash may be investigated for parvovirus B19, rubella and measles immunity in parallel if clinically indicated. The risk of complications associated with parvovirus B19 (such as fetal loss and hydrops fetalis) are highest if infection occurs before 20 weeks gestation.
    • Pregnant women should be always be investigated for immunity to both rubella and parvovirus unless their immune status is already known. If the contact has a laboratory diagnosed rash there is no need to test for both infections. If immunisation history or tests indicate immunity to all viruses under investigation, the woman can be reassured but must be advised to seek medical advice if she develops symptoms.
    • Pregnant women should report all rashes, regardless of known immunity or vaccination status.
  • Asymptomatic infection, or reinfection, may occur [Gershon, 2010], although the prognosis of these conditions is not fully understood [Bouthry, 2014].
Prevention of transmission
  • Guidance from Public Health England states that children with suspected rubella should be kept away from school or nursery for 5 days after the development of the rash [PHE, 2017] and this can be reasonably extrapolated to adults.
  • However, as people can be infectious for 7 days before the onset of the rash to 7-10 days after rash onset [HPA, 2011b; CDC, 2017], CKS recommends it is prudent for the affected person to avoid contact with pregnant women during this time period. Infants with CRS can transmit the virus for up to 1 year after birth [CDC, 2017].
Promote vaccine uptake
  • Rubella is preventable by immunisation with 2 doses of the measles mumps rubella (MMR) vaccine — every opportunity to pick up on missed vaccines and ensure high uptake of the MMR vaccine should be taken [PHE, 2017; PHE, 2018b].
  • Non-immune non-pregnant women should be encouraged to have their antibody status determined and undergo rubella vaccination with MMR if needed [PHE, 2017; Dontigny, 2018; WHO, 2018].
  • Rubella susceptibility screening is offered early in antenatal care (ideally by 10 weeks) to identify women at risk of rubella infection and enable protection of future pregnancies through vaccination postnatally [NICE, 2017].
  • The Public Health England Guidance on Immunisation (Green Book) [PHE, 2013] states that there is no evidence that rubella-containing vaccines are teratogenic, however, as a precaution, MMR vaccine should not be given to women known to be pregnant and if MMR vaccine is given to adult women, they should be advised to guard against pregnancy for one month.
